Rise of Harshavardhana

After the decline of the Gupta Empire, the Pushyabhuti dynasty emerged in Thanesar (Haryana). Prabhakaravardhana was the first significant ruler of this dynasty. His son, Harshavardhana (606тАУ647 CE), is considered the last great Hindu emperor of ancient India. He made Kannauj his capital and unified almost all of North India.

тЪФя╕П
Conquests and Boundaries

Harsha was a great conqueror, but he was stopped from advancing south by the Chalukya king Pulakeshin II on the banks of the Narmada. This battle became a symbol of the balance of power between North and South in Indian history.

ЁЯУЪ
Scholarly Emperor

Harsha was not only a patron of the arts but also a playwright himself (Ratnavali, Priyadarshika, Nagananda). His court was graced by luminaries like Banabhatta (author of 'Harshacharita') and the Chinese traveler Xuanzang. Harsha used to donate everything he possessed at Prayaga every five years.
